title.narrative: F.a: Advancing Sustainable Peace in Myanmar

description.narrative: Civil society’s engagement in the comprehensive process of Peace and Conflict is vital in dealing with 65-years of entrenched mistrust and fear – to move the country forward through reconciliation and a more sustainable peace. While Myanmar’s peace p rocess is expected to advance and building on a positive trend, hopefully strengthened by a positive outcome of the Elections and Ceasefire agreement in 2015, civil society engagement will be crucial to stress as there are few practical entry points – le aving a large part of the population concerned and skeptical of the process and its outcomes. The Main Objective: This project aims to address on-going violence in Rakhine and Kachin State by accompanying and establishing local peacebuilders to develop ini tiatives at local/community level for rights-holders and duty-bearers. Expected Results: • Local peacebuilders and an increasing number of communities have a better understanding of the complex conflict dynamics in Rakhine and Kachin States • Increased engagement and interaction of local actors (government, NGOs, CSOs) in the peace process through increased skills in handling the sensitive issues among participants and building platforms for reconciliation• Peace and Conflict issues are an integral pa rt of and reflected upon in development issues and the governing agenda for local communities• CSO’s play an increasingly important role in P+C issues and represent their constituency better Rights-holders/beneficiaries: groups of local peacebuilders ( different faiths and women representatives) and CSO organisations; increased cooperation with local government as a duty-bearer.Implementing partner:The Centre for Peace and Conflict Studies (CPCS) is a Cambodia-based non-governmental organisation (NGO) wo rking in the field of peace building and conflict transformation in Asia. Its’ mission is to strengthen strategic interventions into armed conflict with the overall goal of reaching sustainable and positive peace in the Asia region. CPCS is home to a ran ge of interconnected programmes and initiatives that are informed by on-going analysis and consultation with a myriad of local partners from the various contexts in which CPCS works, including Myanmar, the Philippines, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.
